licence.p: The transcription of this work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-ShareAlike 4.0 International License. The images are (c) British Library Board (British Library MS Harley 2255) and rights are reserved.

handNote.p: A special note should be made about the forms of the letter "a" throughout. The scribe renders "a," when not in the initial position of a line, in three forms: a two-bow form that is indented slightly, which can be seen in "and" in line seven of the first stanza, a closed-bow form without indenting, as can be seen in "and" at line two of the same stanza, and a slightly more indented vesion where the lower bow is larger than the upper, which can be seen in "amerous" in the first line of stanza five. Whether this is magiscule or miniscule seems dependant on line height, but the scribe is inconsistent regarding their line heights so it's not easy to determine which is intended at particular locations. For this reason I've chosen to render tham all as miniscule.

Magiscule "a" is also rendered in one of three forms if we assume the initial glyph of each line is intended to be magiscule -- which I am not sure can accurately determined. There is a form that is similar to the variable line-height form mentioned above, a form that is similar to this form but with a much deeper bow (as can be seen in "as" in the second line of the second stanza of folio 47), a form with a flattened upper bow and angular lower bow (as can be seen in "A geyn" at line three of that same stanza), a form that is similar to an "A" compressed on both sides (as can be seen in the initial line of the first stanza of folio 50 verso) and a form that is similar to the variable line-height form but with a much more pronounced lower bow and deeper indentation (as can been in "and" at line two of the first stanza of folio 48 verso).

title.title: The Minor Poems of John Lydgate
Edited from all Available MSS., with an Attempt to Establish the Lydgate Canon

zone.line: O how holsom / and glade is the memorye

Of criste IhesuThe scribe consistently strikes a bar through "h" in this witness only when a suspension might be expected. It is most obvious in "ihesu" as it suspends more than one glyph and is the expected suspension, but the "gh" combination of letters is also consistently rendered by barred h as well. / surmountyng al swetnesse
name of conquest / of tryumphe & victorye
Thassaut of Sathan / to venquysshen and oppresse
To which name Seyn Poule berith witnesse
Of heuene and erthe / and Infernal pooste
Alle creaturys of right / and dewe humblesse
And of hool herte / bowe shal ther kne
¶No song so swete vnto the audience
As is ihesus nor so ful of plesaunce
Ageyn al emnyes / sheeld pavys and diffence
To hevy hertys / cheef comfort / in substaunce
Of goostly gladnesse / moost sovereyn Suffisaunce
Cheef directorye / to heueneward / the Cite
Gladdest resoort of spiritual remembraunce
To whom al creaturys / bowe shal ther kne
¶To alle folkys / that stonden in repentaunce
with hert contryt / maad ther confessioun
Of wyl and thought accomplysshed ther penaunce
And to ther poweer / doon Satisfaccioun
That cleyme be mene / of Cristis passioun
Markyd with TavΤThe glyph takes up the full line height, making this a capital tau. It is rendered in gold with red penwork surrounding it. for moor suerte
to them Ihesu / shal graunte ful pardoun
To axe hym mercy / whan they knele on ther kne
¶In this name / foost sovereyn of vertu
Stant hool our hoope and al our assuraunce
ffor wher that evir / namyd is ihesu
Geyn gostly trouble / men fynden allegeaunce
who trustith in ihesu may feele no grevaunce
which from al thraldam / brouht vs to liberte
Out of al servage / he made an acquyntaunce
To alle that knele / to ihesu on ther kne

¶In amerousThe initial glyph here may be capitalized based on its line height in comparison to the other glyphs in the word, but line heights for "a" are fairly inconsistent throughout and so I'm not confident that initial "a" should be rendered in majuscule. hertyes brennyng of kyndenesse
This name of ihesu / moost profoundly doth myne
Martir Ignacius / can bern heerof witnesse
A myd whoos herte / by grace which is divyne
with aureat lettrys / as gold that did shyne
his herte was grave / men may his legende se
To teche al cristene / ther heedys to enclyne
To blissed ihesu and bow a doun ther kne
¶This is the name / that chaceth away the clips
Of fforeyn dirkenesse / as clerkys determyne
By Iohnn remembryd / in thapocalips
how liche a lamb / his heed / he did enclyne
whos blood doun ran / right as any lyne
To wasshe the Orduris / of our Iniquite
Medlyd with watir / cleer and cristallyne
which from his herte doun railed by his kne
¶By blood ihesus made our redempcioun
with watir of baptym / fro felthe wessh vs cleene
And from his herte / too licours ther ran doun
On Caluary / the trouthe was wel seene
Whan longius / with a spere keene
Percyd his herte / vpon the roode
O man vnkynde / thynk what this doth meene
And on to ihesu / bowe a doun thy kne
¶Ther is no speche / for language can remembre
lettir Sillable nor word / that may expresse
thouh in too tungys / were turnyd euery membre
Of man to telle thexcellent noblesse
Of blissed ihesu which of his gret meeknesse
list suffre deth to make his Servaunt fre
Now merciful ihes / for thyn high goodnesse
Haue mercy on alle / that bowe to the ther kne
¶The prince was slayn / the Servaunt went at large
And to delyuer / his soget fro prisoun
The lord took on hym / for to bere the charge
To quyte mankynde / by obligacioun
Seelyd with fyve woundys he payed our raunsoun
Man to restoore / to paradys his Cite
Is man nat bounde / I axe this questioun
To blissed ihesu / for to bowe his kne
¶Six hundryd tyme / with Sixty toold by noumbre
In poulys pistlys / ihesu men may reede
Multitude of feendys / to encombre
To paye our raunsoun / his blood he did sheede
Nat a final part / but al he did out bleede
Ffor Adamys appyl / plukkyd from the tre
Ihesu deyed / for shame man tak heede
Gyf thank to ihesu / and bowe to hym thy kne
¶Alle thes thynges / considred that I tolde
Man / wher evir thu holdist thy passage
toward ihesu / alwey / that thu beholde
with Eye ffyx / looke on his visage
Crownyd with thorn / fo our gret Outrage
haue this in mynde / and lerne o thyng of me
that day noon Enmy shal doon vs noon damage
Whan we to ihesu / devoutly bowe our kne
¶Withynne my closet / and in my litil couche
O blissed ihesu / and by my beddys syde
that noon Enmy / nor no feend shal me touche
The name of ihesu / with me shal evir abyde
My loode sterre / and my sovereyn guyde
In this world heer / bothe on lond and se
O ihesu ihesu / for al tho folk provyde
Which to thy name / devoutly bowe ther kne
¶With Maria / callyd Mawdeleyne
Erly ech morwe / whil that my liff may dure
Ffro slouthe and slombre / my silf I shal restreyne
To seke ihesu / at his sepulture
Whom for to fynde / yif that I may recure
To haue pocessioun of hym at liberte
Ther were in erthe / no richere creature
To whoom al creaturys / bowe shal ther kne
¶in merciful ihesu / to putte a verray preef
Of his mercy / that Noman disespeyre
Vpon the cros / gaf graunt vnto the theef
To paradys / with hym for to repayre
Took out of helle / soulys many apeyre
Mawgre Cerberus / and al his cruelte
O gracious ihesu benygne and debonayre
Haue mercy on all that bowe to the ther kne
¶The name of ihesu swettest of namys alle
Geyn goostly Venyms / holsomest tryacle
Ffor who so evir / vnto this name calle
Of cankryd Surfetys / fynt reles by myracle
To eyen blynde light lanterne and spectacle
And bryghtest myrour / of al felicite
Support and Sheeld/ diffence / and cheef obstacle
To alle that kneele to ihesu on ther kne
¶This roial name / moost sovereyn of renoun
this name ihesus/ victorious in batail
Of heuenly tryvmphis / the laureat guerdoun
The spiritual palme / of goostly appairail
Celestial prowesse / which may moost avail
To Sitte with angelis / in ther eternal se
Themperial conquest / nat gett with plate or mayl
But with meeke keelyng / to to ihesu on our kne
¶Patriarkes and prophetis / oon by oon
thre ierarchyes / and al the orderis nyne
Twelue apostlys / and martirs euerychoon
Hooly confessours / and euery pure virgyne
To blissed ihesu moost meekly shal enclyne
ffonlys beestys / and fisshes of the se
kynde hath taught hem / by natural disciplyne
Meekly to ihesu to bowe a doun ther kne
¶Ther is no love / parfitly I groundid
but it of ihesu / took his Original
ffor vpon ihesu / al parfitnesse is foundid
Our tour our castel / geyn poweers infernal
Our poortcolys / our bolewerk / and our wal
our sheeld / our pavys / geyn al aduersite
Our herytage / our guerdoun eternal
To whoom alle creaturys / bowe shal ther kne
¶Condigne laude / nor Comendacioun
Youe to this name / ther can no tonge telle
Of goostly foode / richest refeccioun
Hedspryng of grace / of lyff conduyt and welle
Ihesu namyd / ther dar no dragoun dwelle
Blissidest bawme / of our felicite
Alle cancryd soorys / and poysouns to repelle
ffrom them / to ihesu / that knele on ther kne
¶This name ihesus / by interpretacioun
Is for to seyne / our blyssid Saviour
Our Strong Sampson / that stranglyd the lioun
Our lord our maker / and our creatour
And by his passioun / fro deth our Redemptour
Our Orpheus that from captyuyte
ffeit Erudice / to his celestial your
To whoom alle creaturys / bowe shal ther kne
¶At wellys five / licour I shal drawe
To wasshe the rust / of my synnys blyve

Wheer al mysteryes / of the Oold and NeweThe extneded descender on the left of the initial glyph, when combined with the magiscule form of "o" in the initial glyph of "Oold," suggests that this is intended to be magiscule as well. Compare with "nayled" in line six of the first stanza of the following page to see the initial form of "n" in miniscule. lawe
Took orygynal / morally to descryve
I meene the wellys / of Cristis woundys five
Wherby we clyme / of merciful pite
thorugh help of ihesu / at gracious poort taryve
Ther to haue mercy / kneelyng on our kne
¶I. in ihesu / set for Iocunditas
Gynnyng and ground / of al goostly gladnesse
E. next in Ordre / is Eternitas
Tokne and signe / of eternal brightnesse
S. Set for Sanitas / socour ageyn syknesse
V. for vbertas / of Spiritual plente
S. for Suauitas / from whom comyth al swetnesse
To them that kneele / to Ihesu on ther kne
¶I. in ihesu / is ioye / that nevir shal eende
E. signefieth / evirlastyng Suffisaunce
S. our Savacioun / whan we shal hens weende
V. his five woundys / that made vs aquytaunce
ffro Sathanys myght thorugh his meeke Suffraunce
S. for the Sacrament / which ech day we may se
In fourme of breed / to save vs from myschaunce
Whan we devoutly / receyve it on our kne
¶I. fro Iacob / H. from Abraham
The lyne descendyng / by generacioun
C. stant for Crist / that from heuene cam
Born of a mayde / for our Redempcioun
the sharpe titel / tokne of his passioun
Whan he was nayled / vpon the Roode tre
O blidded Ihesu / do remyssioun
To alle that axe mercy / on ther kne
¶So mercy ihesu / or that we hens pace
Out of this pereillous dreedful pilgrymage
beset with brygauntys / leyd wayt in euery place
With mortal sawt / to lettyn our passage
Among othre / I that am falle in age
Gretly ffeblisshed / of Oold Infirmyte
Crye vnto Ihesu / for my Synful outrages
Right of hool herte / thus kneelyng on my kne
¶Lat nat be lost / that thu hast bought So deere
with gold nor Silver / but with thy precious blood
Our fflesshethe "h" is barred here, so my assumption is that this is meant to indicate terminal "e." is freel / but short abydyng heere
The Oold Serpent / malicious and wood
the world vnstable / now ebbe / now is flood
Ech thyng concludyng / on Mutabilite
Geyn whos daungeers / I hold this consayl good
To prey for mercy / to ihesu on our kne
¶And vndir Suppoort / ihesu of thy favour
Or I passe hens / this hoolly myn entent
To make Ihesu / to be cheef Surveyour
Of my laste wyl / set in my testament
Which of my silf / am insufficient
To rekne or counte / but mercy and pite
be preferryd / or thu do Iugement
To alle that calle / to ihesu on ther kne
¶Age is crope in / callith me to my grave
To make reknyng / how I my tyme haue spent
bareyn of vertu / allas / who shal me save
ffro feendys daunger / tacounte for my Talent
but ihesu be my staff / and my potent
Ovir streyt Audit / is lik tencoumbre me
Or doom be yove / but mercy be present
To alle that kneele / to ihesu on ther kne
¶Now in the name / of my lord Ihesus
Of right hool herte / in al my best entent
My lyff remembryng / froward and vicious
Ay contrary to the Comaundement
Of Crist ihesu / Now with avisement
The lord besechyng / to haue mercy and pite
My youthe myn Age / how that I haue myspent
With this woord seyd / keelyng on my kne
¶O ihesu mercy / with suppoort of thy grace
ffor thy meek passioun / remembre on my compleynt
Duryng my lyf / with many gret trespace
By many wrong path / wher I haue myswent
I now purpoose / by thy grace influent
To write a tretys / of Surfetys doon to the
And callyn it / my last testament
With ihesu mercy / kneelyng on my kne

line.note: This is rendered in red to the right of the first stanza of part two. This, rather than an illuminated initial, indicates the beginning of part II of the "Testament."

zone.line: ¶The yeerys passyd / of my tendir youthe
Off my fressh age / seryd the grennesse
lust appallyd thexperience is towthe
The vnweedly Ioyntes / starkyd with rudnesse
the cloudy sighte mystyd with dirknesse
withoute redres / recure or amendys
To me of deth / han brought in the kalendys
¶Of myspent tyme / a fool may weel compleyne
Thyng impossible / ageyn for to recure
Dayes lost in ydil / no man may restreyne
Them to refourme / by noon aventure
Eche mortal man / is callid to the lure
Of deth allas vncerteyn the passage
whos cheef maryneer / is callyd crokyd age
¶Oon of his bedellys / namyd febilnesse
Cam with his potent / in stede of a maas
Somowned me / and aftir cam syknesse
Malencolyk erthely / adThis is meant to be "and", but the scribe omitted the "n" in the middle of the word pale of faas
with ther waraunt / thes tweyne gan manaas
how deth of me / his dew dette soughte
And to a bed / of langour / they me broughte
¶Wher vnto me / anoon ther did appeere
Whyl that I lay / compleynyng in a traunce
Clad in a mantyl / a woman sad of cheere
Blak was hir habite / sobre was hir contenaunce
Straunge of hir poort / froward and daliaunce
Castyng hir look / to me ward in certeyn
lych as of me / she had disdeyn
¶This sayd woman / was callyd Remembraunce
Of myspent tyme / in youthys lustynesse
Which to recorde did me gret grevaunce
than cam hir sustir / namyd Pensiffnesse
ffor olde surfetys / and gan vnto me dresse
A wooful bille / which brought vnto my mynde
My grete outrages / of long tyme left behynde
¶Lyggyng allone / I gan to ymagyne
How with foure tymes / departyd is the yeer
ffirst how in Ver / the soyl tenlvmyne
buddys gyme opne / ageyn the sonne cleer
the bawme vp reysed / moost sovereyn & enteer

Out of the Roote / doth naturally ascendeThis appears to be "st" at first, especially when compared with "distillyng" in the following stanza and "lustynesse" on the third stanza of the page prior. However, comparison with "ascencioun" on 53 verso, stanza three suggests that what is seen as an ascender is actually an otiose mark.
With newe lyvere / the bareyn soyl tamende
¶The honysoucle / the froisshe prymerollys
ther levys splaye / at Phebus vprysyng
The amerous fowlys / with motetys & Carollys
Salwe that sesoun / euery morwenyng
Whan Aurora / hir licour distillyng
Sent on herbys / the peerly dropys sheene
Of silvir dewys / tenlvmyne with the greene
¶This tyme Ver / is namyd of grennesse
tyme of Ioye / of gladnesse and dispoort
Tyme of growyng cheef moodir of fresshenesse
tyme of reioisshyng / ordeyned for counfoort
Tyme whan tyme / makith his resoort
In gerysshe Marche / toward the Ariete
Our Emysperye / to gladen with his hete
¶Which sesoun / pryketh fresshe corages
Reioisshithe beestys / walkyng in ther pasture
Causith briddys / to syngen in ther cages
Whan blood renewyth / in euery creature
Som observaunce / doyng to nature

WhichnaturaAn otiose mark, followed by "natura", is above "which" in this line. This appears to be a correction of "nature" in the previous line but there are no marks indicating that the line is struck through. Additionally, the rhyme scheme does not support the word "natura" here so it's unclear what the intend of the word's inclusion here is. is of ver / callyd cheef pryncesse
And vndir god / ther worldly Emperesse
¶And for this lusty sesoun agreable
of gladnesse / hath so gret avauntage
by convenyent resouns / ful notable
therto ful weel / resemblith childisshe age
Quyk greene fresshe / and delyvere of corage
ffor right as Ver / ay moreth in grennesse
so doth childhood / in amerows lustynesse
¶This quykyng sesoun / nutrityff and good
Of his nature / hath tweyne qualitees
Of hoot and moyst / whigh longe also to blood
In ther ascencioun / vpward by degrees
Of kyndly right / the which propirtees
by natural heete / and temperat moisture
Reknyd in childhod / fourtene yeer doth endure
¶Thus in sixe thynges / by ordre men may seen
Notable accoord / and iustThe EETS edition has "lust" here. convenience
Blood Eyr / an ver / southe / and Merydien
And age of Childhood / by natural assistence
Which whil they stonde / in ther fressh premynence
Heete and moysture / directyth ther passages
With greene feruence / tafforce yong corages
¶ffirst zephirus / with his blastys soote
Enspireth ver / with newe buddys greene
the bawme ascendithe / out of every Roote
Causyng with flourys / ageyn the sonne sheene
May / among monethys / sitte lyk a queene
Hir sustir April / wattryng hir gardynes
With holsom shouris / shad in the tendyr vynes
¶This tyme of Ver / fflora / doth hir cure
With pleyn motles / passyng fresshe and gaye
Purpil clours / wrought / wrouht by dame nature
Mounteyns valys / and meedewys for taraye
Hir warderobe open / list nat to delaye
large mesour / to shewe out and to sheede
tresours / of ffayrye / which she doth poosseede
¶This sesoun Ver / moost plesaunt to childhood
with hire chapelettys / greene whit and Reede
In which tyme / the newe yonge blood
hoot and moyst / ascendith vp in deede
Reioisshyng hertys / as it a brood doth spreede
Weenyng this sesoun among ther merthis alle
Shuld nevir discresen / nor appalle
¶The variaunt sesoun / of this stormy age
Abraydeth evere / on newfangilnesse
Now frownyng cheer / now fressh of visage
Now glad now light / now trouble and hevynesse
Wylde as an hert / now moornyng for sadnesse
Stormysshe as Marche / with chaungis ful sodeyne
Afftir cleer shynyng / to tourne & make it reyne
¶Off this sesoun / lust halt Reyne and brydil
Seelde or nevir / abydyng in o poynt
Now passyng besy / now dissolut / now ydil
Now a good felawe / now al out of ioynt
Now Smothe now stark / now lyk an hard purporynt
Now as the peys / of a dyal goth
Now gerysshe glad / and anoon aftir wrothe
¶Lych as in Ver / men gretly them delite
to beholde / the bewte sovereyne
Of thes blosmys / Som blew / red and white
to whos fresshnesse / no colour may atteyne
But than vnwarly / comyth a wynd sodeyne
ffor no favour / list nat for to spare
ffresshnesse of braunchys / for to make hem bare
¶This sesoun Ver stant evir in nouncerteyne
ffor som Oon hour / though phebus fresshely shyne
In Marchys Wedrys / it sodeynly wil Reyne
Which of the day / al dirknesse doth declyne
And semblably / a lyknesse to diffyne
Men seen childre / of berthe yong and greene
Buryed witheyne
¶Whan Ver is fresshest / of blosmys & of flourys
An vnwar storm / his fresshnesse may apayre
Who may withstonde / the sterne sharp shourys
Of dethys power wher hym list repayre
though the feturis / fresshe angelik and fayre
Shewe out in childhood / as any cristal cleer
Dethe can difface hem / witheyne fyfteene yeer
¶Veris sesoun / doth but a while abyde
Skarsly thre monethys / he holdith heer soiour
The age of childhood / rekne on the tothir syde
In his encrees vp growyng / as a flour
But whan that deth / manacithe with his shour
In such caas / he can / no moor diffence
Than crokyd age / in his moost impotence
¶Ver and ech sesoun / mot by processe fade
In ver / of age / may be no sekirnesse
Eche hath his hourys / heuy and eek glade
ther sesouns meynt / with Ioye and hevynesse
Now fayr now foul / now helithe now siknesse
To shew amaner / lyknesse and ymage
Our dwellyng heer / is but a pilgrymage
¶And for my part / I can remembre weel
Whan I gladdest / in that fresshe sesoun
lyk brotyl glas / nat stable / nor lyk steel
ffer out of arrest / wylde of condicioun
SavagyneThe EETS edition has "Ful geryssh" here. / voyd of al resoun
lyk a phane / ay tornyng to and froo
Or lyk / a horloge / whan the peys is goo

line.note: This is to the left of the final word on the page, rendered in red.

zone.line: ¶Yove to vnthrift / and dissolucioun
stood vnbrydlyd / of al good governaunce
Which remembryd / by meetk confessioun
Now with my potent / to fynden allegeaunce
Of Oold surfetys / contryt with repentaunce
To the ihesu / I make my passage
Rehersyng respacys doon in my tendir age
¶But to directe / by grace my mateere
Meekly kneelyng / ihesu in thy presence
I me purpoose / to gynne with prayeere
Vndir thy merciful fructuous influence
So thu ihesu / of thy benyvolence
To my requestys / by merciful attendaunce
Graunt or I deye / shrift hosyl repentaunce
¶My wrecchyd lyf / tamenden and correcte
I me purpoose / with support of thy grace
thy deth / thy passioun / thy cros τ . shal me directe
Which suffredist deeth / ihesu for our trespace
I wrecche vnworthy / to looke vpon thy face
thy feet enbracyng / from whiche I shal nat twynne
Mercy requeeryng thus I wyl begynne
O myhty lord / of poweer myhtiest
With oute whom / al force is febilnesse
bountevous ihesu / of good goodliest
Mercy thy bedel / or thu thy doomys dresse
delayest / rigour / to punysshe my wikkydnesse
lengest abydyng / lothest to do vengaunce
O blyssed ihesu / of thyn high goodnesse
Graunt or I deye shrift hosyl repentaunce

line.note: This is rendered in red to the right of the two-line initial.

zone.line: ¶Though thu be myghty / thu art Eek merciable
to alle folkys / that meekly hem repente
I a wrecche / contagious / and Coupable
To alle outrages / reedy for tassente
but of hool herte and wyl in myn entente
Of Oold and newe / al vicious governaunce
Of youthe of age / and of mystyme spente
Graunt or I deye / shrift hosyl repentaunce
¶Off my confessioun / receyve the sacrefise
By my tonge / vp offryd vnto the
That I may seyn / in al my beste guyse
Meekly with Dauid / haue mercy vpon me
Sauf al my Soorys / that they nat cankryd be
With noon oold rust / of disesperaunce
which of hool herte / crye vpon my kne
Graunt or I deye / shrift hosyl repentaunce
¶O ihesu ihesu / heere myn orisoun
brydle myn outrage / vndir thy disciplyne
ffetre sensualite / Enlvmyne my resoun
To folwe the tracys / of spiritual doctryne
lat thy grace / leede me right as lyne
With humble herte / to live to thy plesaunce
And blissed ihesu / or I this liff shal ffyne
Graunt of thy mercy / shrift hosil repentaunce
¶Suffre me to haue / savour nor swetnesse
but in thy name / that callid is ihesu
Al foreyn thyng / to me make bittirnesse
Sauf oonly ihesu / moost sovereyn of vertu
to my professioun / accordyng / and moost dew
Evere to be preentyd / in my remembraunce
At myn Eende / to graunte me this issu
To for my deth / shrift hosil repentaunce
¶No lord but ihesu / moost merciable & benygne
Which of mercy / took our humanyte
And of love / to shewe a sovereyn signe
Suffredist passioun vpon the Roode tre
Oonly to fraunchise / our mortalite
Which stood in daunger of Sathanys encoumbraunce
Or I passe hens / ihesu graunt vnto me
To for my deth / shrift hosil repentaunce
¶I am excited / and meevyd of nature
This name of ihesu / sovereynly to preyse
Name comendid / moost highly in scripture
Which name hath poweer / dede men to reise
To liff Eternal / whos vertu doth so peyse
A geyn my synnes / weyed in ballaunce
that grace and mercy / shal so countirpeyse
Graunt or I deye / shrift hosyl repentaunce
¶Lat me nat reste nor haue no quyete
Occupye my soule / with spiritual travayl
to synge and seyn / o mercy ihesu swete
My proteccioun / geyn feendys in batayl
Sette a syde / al othir apparayl
And in ihesu / put hool myn affiaunce
tresour of tresouris / that me moost avayl
Graunt or I deye / shift hosyl repentaunce
¶Myn feith / myn hoope / to the ihesu doth calle
Which glorious name / shal nevir out of mynde
I shal the seeke / what hap that evyr be falle
by grace and mercy / in trust I shal the fynde
And but I did / trewly I were vnkynde
which for my sake / wer percyd with a launce
vnto the herte / ihesu leff nat behynde
Graunt or I deye / shrift hosyl repentaunce
¶Ther is no god / but thu ihesu allone
Sovereynest / and eek moost merciful
ffayrest of fair / erly late and soone
Stable and moost strong / pitous and rightful
Refourmyng / synners / that been in vertu dul
Dawntyng the proude / meeknesse to enhaunce
thy toune of mercy / is evir I lichee ful
Graunt or I deye / shrift hosyl repentaunce
¶Suffre of mercy / I may to the speke
O blissed ihesu / and goodly do aduerte
Who shal yeve me leiser / out to breke
that thu ihesu / mayst entren in myn herte
ther tabyde / moor neer than my sherte
With Aureat lettris / grave ther in substeraunce

Provide for me / and lat it nat asterteIt's tempting to read this as "afterte," but if one looks closely at the crosses of the "a" and "t" they terminate just before the ascender of the second glyph. When compared with the "f of "suffre" in the first line of the stanza and the "st" ligature throughout it seems this is a deliberate decision by the scribe. This further reinforces it's "asterte," as expected.
Graunt or I deye shrift hosyl repentaunce
¶Sey to my soule ihesu / thu art myn helthe
heeryng this wys / aftir I shal purswe
Skore that place / from al goostly felthe
And vice alle fro thens do remwe
Thyn hooly goost / close in that litil mwe
parte nat lightly / mak such chevisaunce
tencrese in vert / and vices to schewe
And or I deye / shrift hosyl repentaunce
¶Shew glad thy face / and thy light doun sheede
the merciful light / of thyn eyen tweyne
On me thy servaunt / which hath so mooche neede
for his synnes / to weepen and compleyne
And blissed ihesu / of mercy nat disdeyne
thy gracious shourys / lat reyne in habundaunce
Vpon myn herte / tadewen every veyne
And or I deye / shrift hosyl repentaunce
¶Save me thy servaunt / o lord in thy mercy
ffor lak of which / lat me nat be confoundid
for in the ihesu / myn hoope stant fynally
And al my trust / in the ihesu is groundid
ffor my synnes / thynk ihesu thu were woundid
Nakid on the Roode / by mortal gret penaunce
by which the poweer of sathan was confoundid
Graunt or I deye / shrift hosyl repentaunce
¶Thu art ihesu / my socour and refuge
geyn every tempest / and tribulacioun
that worldly wawes / with ther mortal deluge
Ne drowne me nat / in ther dreedful dongoun
wher karibdys / hath domynacioun
And Circes syngeth / songis of disturbaunce
to passe that daunger / be my proteccioun
Graunt or I deye / shrift hosyl repentaunce
¶Who shal give me / lych to myn entent
that thu ihesu / maist make thyn herbergage
by receyvyng / of thooly sacrament
In to myn herte / which is to myn Oold age
Repast Eternal / geyn al foreyn damage
dewly receyved / with devout observaunce
Celestial guerdoun / eende of my pilgrymage
Is shrift hosyl / and hertly repentaunce
¶I feele myn herte / brotel / and Ruynous
Nat purefied / ihesu ther in to reste
but as a carpenteer / comyth to a broken hous
Or an artificeer / reparith a Riven cheste
So thu ihesu / of craffty men the beste
Repare my thought / broke with mysgovernaunce
Visite my soule / myn herte of steel thu breste
Graunt or I deye / shrift hosyl repentaunce
¶With wepyng eyen / and a contryt cheer
Accepte me ihesu / and my compleynt conceyve
As moost vnwurthy / tapeere at thyn awteer
Whichein my silf / no vertu apparceyve
but yif thy mercy by grace me receyve
by synful lyvyng brought vnto vttraunce
Preye with good hoope / which may me nat deceyve
Graunt or I deye / shrift hosyl repentaunce
¶Cryeng to the / that deydest on the Rood
which with thy blood / wer steyned & maad Reed
And on Sheerthursday / gaf vs to our food
Thy blissed boody / ihesu in foorme of breed
to me moost synful / graunt or I be deed
To cleyme by mercy / for myn enheritaunce
that with sharp thorn / wer crownyd on thyn heed
Or I passe hens / shryfft hosyl repentaunce
¶And Oon requeste / inThere is a mark over the second minim which may be a tittle or an otiose mark. especial
Graunt me ihesu / whyl I am heer alyve
Evir haue enprentyd / in my memorial
the Remembraunce / of thy woundys five
Naylles with the spere / that did thyn herte Ryve
Thy crown of thorn / which was no smal penaunce
language and tonge / me dewly for to shryve
the hooly vnccioun / shrift hosyl repentaunce
¶Alle the tokyns / of thy passioun
I pray the ihesu / grave hem in my memorye
dewly marke / myd Centre of my resoun
On Caluary / thy tryvmphal victorye
Man to restoore / to thyn eternal glorye
by mediacioun / of thy meeke suffraunce
out of this exil vnswre and transitorye

And whan I passe / shrifft holylThe third glyph of this word should be "s" so this is a scribal error. It may also suggest a misreading of the exemplar as "hosyl" appears repeatedly throughout the witness. repentaunce
¶Of thy mercy requeryng the to myne
of my mynde / the myd poynt / moost profounde
this woord ihesu / my fyve wittys tenlvmyne
In lengthe and breede / lyk a large woundeThere is what appears to be a supension on terminal "e," but a suspension does not fit with the rhyme scheme of the stanza. Therefore, it's an otiose mark.
Al ydel thouhtis / tavoyde hem and confounde
thy cros thy scorgis / thy garnement cast at chaunce
The Rope the piler to which thu wer bounde
Graunt or I deye / Shrift hosil repentaunce
¶Of this prayeer / meekly I make an eende
vndir thy merciful / supportacioun
O gracious ihesu / graunt wher evir I weende
to haue memory / vpon thy passioun
Testimonial / of my Redempcioun
In my testament / set for allegaunce
This clause last / of my peticioun
Graunt or I deye / shrift hosil repentaunce

DuryngUnlike the initial beginning parts, three, and five this is only a single line initial. That said, it is illuminated and decorated similarly to the initials beginning the other sections. It may be the lack of spacing for the initial underneath prevented this from being a two-line initial. the tyme of this sesoun ver
I meene the sesoun of my yeerys greene
Gynnyng from childhood / strecchithe vp so fer

to yeOther witnesses as well the EETS edition have "the" here, and my suspicion is that the exemplar the scribe was copying from used thorn rather than "th." There is nothing to indicate a difference between the initial glyph of this word and glyphs rendered as "y" elsewhere (as in the next word in this line). Since this manuscript does not typically use thorn, I have chosen to render this as "ye." yeerys / accountyd ful ffifteene
bexperience / as it was weel seene
The gerisshe sesoun / straunge of condiciouns
dispoosyd to many vnbridlyd passiouns
¶Voyd of resoun / yove to wilfulnesse
ffroward to vertu / of thrift gaf litil heede
loth ot lerne / lovid no besynesse
sauf pley or merthe / straunge to spelle or reede
ffolwyng al appetites / longyng to childheede
lihtly tournyng wylde / and seelde sade
weepyng for nought / and anoon afftir glad
¶ffor litil wroth / to scryve with my felawe
as my passiouns / did my bridil leede
Of the yeerde somtyme / I stood in awe
to be scooryd / that was al my dreede
loth toward scole / lost my tyme in deede
lik a yong colt / that ran with owte brydil
Made my freendys / ther good to spende in ydil
¶I hadde in custom / to come to scole late
Nat for to lerne / but for a contenaunce
with my felawys / reedy to debate
to Iangle and and Iape / was set al my plesaunce
Wherof rebukyd / this was my chevisaunce
to forge a lesyng / and therupon to muse
whan I trespasyd / my silven to excuse
¶To my bettre / did no reverence
Of my soveryns / gaf no fors at al
Wex obstynat / by inobedience
Ran in to gardyns / applys ther I stal
To gadre frutys sparyd hegg nor wal
to plukke grapys in othir mennys vynes
Was moor reedy / than for to seyn matynes
¶My lust was al / to storne folk and iape
shrewde tornys / evir among to vse
to skoffe and mowe / lyk a wantoun ape
whan I did evil / othre I did accuse
My wittys five / in wast I did abuse
Rediere chirstoonys / for to telle
Than gon to chirche / or heere the sacry belle
¶Loth to ryse / lother to bedde at eve
with vnwassh handys / reedy to dyneer
My pater noster / my Crede / or my beleeve
Cast at the Cok / loo this was my maneer
wavid with ech wynd / as doth a reed speer
snybbyd of my frendys / such techechys fortamende
Made deff ere / lyst nat / to them attende
¶A child resembylng / which was nat lyk to thryve
ffroward to god / reklees in his servise
loth to correccioun / slough my sylf to shryve
Al good thewys / reedy to despise
Cheef bellewedir / of feyned trwaundise
this is to meene / my silf I cowde feyne
Syk lyk a trwaunt / felte no maneer peyne
¶My poort my pas / my foot alwey vnstable
my look myn eyen / vnswre and vagabounde
In al my werkys / sodeynly chaungable
To al good thewys / contrary I was founde
Now ovir sad / now moornyng / now iocounde
Wilful rekles / mad stertyng as an hare
To folwe my lust / for no man wold I spare
¶Entryng this tyme / in to Religioun
Vnto the plough / I putte forth myn hoond
A yeer compleet / made my professioun
Considryng litil charg / og thilke boond
Of perfeccioun / ful good exaumple I foond
the techyng good / in me was al the lak
With lootys wyff / I lookyd ofte bak
¶Taught of my maistris / by vertuous disciplyne
My look restreyne / and keepe clos my sight
Of blyssed Benyt / to folwe the doctryne
And ber me lowly / to euery maneer wight
by the advertence / of myn inward sight
Cast to godward / of hool affeccioun
To folwe themprises / of my professioun
¶His hooly rewle / was vnto me rad
And expowndyd / in ful notable wise
by vertuous men / Religious and sad
fful weel expert / discreet prudent and wise
And observauncys / of many goostly emprise
i herd al week / but touchyng to the deede
Of that they taughte / I took but litil heede
¶Of religioun / I weryd a blak habite
oonly outward / as by apparence
to folwe that charge / savouryd but ful lite
Sauf by a maneer countirfet pretence
but in effect ther was noon existence
lyk the ymage / of Pygmalioon
shewyd liffly / and was nat but of stoon
¶Vpon the laddere / with stavys thryves thre
The nyne degrees / of vertuous meeknesse
Callyd in the rewle / grees of hvmylite
Wheron tascende / my feet me lyst nat dresse
but by a maneer / feyned fals humblesse
So covertly / whan folkys wer present
Oon to shewe outward / another in myn entent
¶ffirst wher as I forsook myn owne wil
Shett with a lok of Obedyence
tobeye my sovereyns / as it was right and skil
to folwe the scoole of parfight pacience
to my Eynes / doon worship and reverence
ffolwyng the Revers / took al a nothir weye
What I was bodyn I cowde wel disobeye
¶With tonge at large / and brotil conscience
fful of woordys / disordynat of language
Rekles to keepe my lippys in silence
Mouth eye and eerys / tooke ther avauntage
To haue ther cours / vnbrydlid by outrage
Out of Reynes / of attemperaunce
To Sensualite / gaff al the governaunce
¶Wacche out of tyme Ryot and dronkenesse
Vnfructuous talkyng / Imtemperat diete
to veyn fablys / I did myn eerys dresse
ffals detraccioun / among was to me swete
to talke of vertu me thouht it was not mete
To my corage / nor my compleccioun
Nor nouht that sownyd / toward perfeccioun
¶Oon with the firste to take my dispoort
last that aroos / to come to the queer
In contemplacioun / I fond but smal counfoort
Hooly historyes / did to me no cheer
I savouryd mor / in good wyn that was cleer
And every honrThe third glyph looks more like an "n," but it's likely that this is meant to be "hour" rather than "honr" / my passage for to dresse
As I seide erst / to Ryot or excesse
¶Kowde grucche / and fond no cause why
Causelees ofte / compleyned on my fare
Geyn my correcciouns / answeryd frowardly
Withoute Reverence / lyst noman to spare
Of al vertu / and pacience / I was bare
of Reklees youthe / lyst noon heed to take
What crist ihesu suffryd for my sake
¶Which now remembryng / in my latter age
tyme of my childhood / as I reherse shal
witheyne ffifteene / holdyng my passage
MidThe first glyph should be a magiscule "M," but it appears to be very oddly constructed here. of a cloistre / depict vpon a wal
I saugh a Crucifix / whos woundys were nat smal
With this woord vide / writen ther besyde
behold my meeknesse / o child / and lef thy pride
¶The which woord / whan I did vndirstonde
In my last Age / takyng the sentence
theron Remembryng / my penne I took in honde
gan to write / with humble reverence
On this woord vide / of humble dilligence
In Remembraunce / of cristis passioun
this litil dite / this compilacioun
BE hoold o man left vp thyn eye and see

What mortal peyne / I tsuffrydThe scribe originally started the word with a "t, then corrected by overwriting with "s." This is clear by the hook on the lower end of the minim. Thus what appears to be the crossbar of an "f" is actually the crossbar of the overwritten "t." for thy trespace
with pitous voys / I crye and sey to the
behoold my woundys / behold my bloody face
Behold the Rebukys / that do me so manace
behold myn emnyes / that do me so despise
And how that I / to refourme the to grace
Was like a lamb / offryd in sacrifise
Be holdThe catchword can be seen on the lower right portion of the page, but it has been half cut by later trimming of the manuscript.
¶Behold the paynemys / of whom I was take
behold the cordys / with which that I was bounde
Behold the Armwrys / which made myn herte quake
behold the gardyn / in which that I was founde
Behold how Iudas took thrytty penyes rounde
behoold his tresoun / behold his covetise
Behold how I / with many a mortal wounde
Was lyk a lamb / offryd in sacrifise
¶See my disciple / which that hath me sold
And see his feyned / fals salutacioun
And see the mony / which that he hath told
And see his kissyng / of fals decepcioun
behold laso / the compassyd fals tresoun
take as a theef / with lanternys in ther guyse
And aftirward / for mannys redempcioun
Was like a lamb / offryd in sacrifise
¶Behold to Caiphas / how I was presentyd
behold how Pilat / list geve me no respyt
behold how bisshopis / wer to my deth assentyd
And see how herowd / had me in despit
And lik a fool / how I was clad in whit
Drawen as a feloun / in moost cruel wyse
And last of alle / I aftir ther delit
Was like a lamb / offryd in sacrifise
¶Behold the mynystrys / which had me in keepyng
behold the piler / and the roopis stronge
wher I was bounde / my sides doun bleedyng
Moost felly beete / with ther scoorgis longe
behold the batail / that I did vndirfonge
the bront abydyng / of ther mortal emprise
Thorugh ther accusyng / and ther sclaundrys wronge
Was like a lamb / offryd in sacrifise
¶Behold and see / the hatful wrecchidnesse
Put ageyn me / to my confusioun
Myn eyen hyd / and blyndid with derknesse
bete and Eek bobbid / by fals illusioun
Salwed in scorn / by ther fals knelyng doun
Behold al this / and see the mortal guyse
how I oonly / for mannys savacioun
Was like a manb / offrid in Sacrifise
¶See the witnessis / by whom I was deceyved
behold the Iugis / that gaf my Iugement
Behold the cros / that was for me devised
behold my boody / with betyng al to rent
Behold the peeple / which of fals entent
Causelees / did ageyns me rise
Which like a lamb/ of malys Innocent
was for mankynde / offrid in sacrifise
¶Behold the women / that folwyd me aferre
that sore wepte / whan I thus was assailed
behold the Iewys / which by ther cruel werre
Han my body / vnto a cros I nayled
behold my tormentys / moost sharply apparailed
Attween too thevys / put to my
beholde how moche / my deth hath eek avayled
that was for man / offrid in sacrifise
¶Behold the spere / moost sharply grounde & whet
Myn herte woundid / vpon the right syde
behold the reed speer / galle and eysel fett
Behold the scornyngis / which that I did abyde
And my five woundys / that were maad so wyde
Which noman lyst / of routhe to advertise
And thus I was / of meeknesse ageyn pryde
ffo mannys offence / offrid in sacrifise
¶See my disciplis / how they ha me forsake
And fro me fled / almoost everychon
See how theisleepte / and list nat with me wake
Of mortal dreed / they lefft me al allon
Except my moodir / and my cosyn seyn Iohnn
My deth compleynyng / in moost doolful wise
See fro my cros / they wolde nevir gon
ffor mannys offence / whan I did sacrifise
¶See how I / was Iugid to the deth
See Baraban / goon at his liberte
See with a speere / how longius me sleth
behold too licouris / distyllyng doun fro me
See blood and watir / by merciful plente
Rayle by my sides / which aughte I nough suffise
To man / whan I vpon the roode tre
was like a lamb / offrid in sacrifise
¶Behold the knyghtis / which by ther froward chaunce
Sat for my clothys / at the dees to pleye
behold my moodir / swownyng / for frevaunce
vpon the cros / whan she saugh me deye
behold the sepulcre / in which my boonys leye
kept with strong wacche / tyl I did arrise
Of helle gatys / see how I brake he keye
And gaf for man / my blood in sacrifise
¶Ageyn thy pryde / behold my gret meeknesse
Geyn thyn envye / behold my charite
geyn thy lechreye / behold my caast clennesse
Geyn thy Covetise / behold my poverte
Attween too theevys / nayled to a tre
Railed with reed blood / they list me to disguyse
behold o man / al this I did for the
Meek as a lamb / offrid in sacrifise
¶Behold my love / and gif me thyn ageyn
behold I deyed / thy raunsoun for to paye
See how myn herte / is open brood and pleyn
thy goostly emnyes / oonly to affraye
An hardere batayl / noman myght assaye
Of alle tryvmphes / the grettest high emprise
Wherfor o man / no lenger the dismaye
I gaff my blood / for the in sacrifise
¶Turne hoom ageyn / thy synne do forsake
Behold and see / yif ought be lefft behynde
How I to mercy / am redy the to take
Gyff me thyn herte / and be no mor vnkynde
thy love and myn / to gidre do hem bynde
And let hem nevir parte in no wyse
whan thu wer lost / thy soule ageyn to fynde
My blood I offryd / for the in sacrifise
¶Enprente thes thynges / in thyn inward thought
And grave hem deepe / in thy remembraunce
Thynk on hem weel / and forgete hem nought
Al this I suffryd / to do the allegaunce
And with my seyntis / to yeve the suffisaunce
In the heuenly court / for the I so devise
A place eternal / of al plesaunce
ffor which my blood / I gaff in sacrifise
¶And mor my mercy / to putten at a preeff
To euery synnere / that noon ne shal it mys
Remembre / how I gaf mercy to the theeff
Which had so long / trespacyd and doon a mys
went he nat freely / with me to paradys
Ha this in mynde / how it is my guyse
Alle repentaunt / to bryng hem to my blys
ffor whom my blood / I gaf in sacrifise
¶Tarye no lenger / toward thyn heritage
Hast on thy weye / and be of right good cheer
Go ech day onward / on thy pilgrymage
thynk how short tyme / thu shalt abyde heer
Thy place is biggyd / a bove the sterrys cleer
noon erthely paleyes / my brothir moost enteer
Com on my freend / my brothir moost enteer
ffor the I offryd / my blood in sacrifise
Explicit testament
